description: Zero-shot VLM baseline for walkability assessment. Point-based aggregation without sequential analysis.
description_cn: Zero-shot VLM baseline for walkability assessment. Point-based aggregation without sequential analysis.
theory_base: OpenStreetMap + Google Street View + LLaVA Integration
paper_reference: SAGAI (2025) - Street-level Accessibility and Greenery Assessment using AI

method.model_approach: Direct image scoring with prompt-engineered reasoning across multiple evaluation tasks

aggregation_method.description: Simple mean and sum aggregation without considering spatial transitions
aggregation_method.description_cn: Simple mean and sum aggregation without considering spatial transitions
aggregation_method.contrast_with_sequential: No volatility analysis, no hidden barrier detection, no transition weighting

validation_metrics.notes: Good for baseline comparison, traditional walkability scores

dimensions.theory_base: SAGAI baseline dimension - pedestrian safety assessment
dimensions.description: Evaluate pedestrian safety: traffic separation, lighting, surface quality, and visibility.
dimensions.vlm_prompt:
Please evaluate the **Safety** of this street view image.

Focus on:
- Traffic protection: Vehicle speeds, separation between people and cars, crossings, and signals.
- Lighting: Daytime shading and nighttime fixtures that keep the path visible.
- Surface quality: Sidewalk smoothness, maintenance, curb ramps, and other accessible features.
- Visibility: Clear sightlines with minimal blind spots.

Rate the scene from 1-10 (1 = very unsafe, 10 = very safe) and explain the score in 2-3 English sentences.

Respond in JSON:
{"score": <number 1-10>, "reasoning": "<English explanation>"}

dimensions.theory_base: SAGAI baseline dimension - pedestrian comfort assessment
dimensions.description: Evaluate walking comfort: width, shade, rest options, and perceived pleasantness.
dimensions.vlm_prompt:
Please evaluate the **Comfort** of this street view image.

Focus on:
- Width: Is the walkway generous enough to avoid crowding?
- Weather protection: Are there trees, canopies, or other forms of shade and shelter?
- Resting amenities: Are there benches or informal places to pause?
- Environmental pleasantness: Consider noise, heat, and air quality cues.

Rate the scene from 1-10 (1 = very uncomfortable, 10 = very comfortable) and explain the score in 2-3 English sentences.

Respond in JSON:
{"score": <number 1-10>, "reasoning": "<English explanation>"}

dimensions.theory_base: SAGAI baseline dimension - visual interest and engagement
dimensions.description: Evaluate visual richness and activity cues that make the walk engaging.
dimensions.vlm_prompt:
Please evaluate the **Interest** level of this street view image.

Focus on:
- Visual richness: Variety of buildings, landscape, signage, or art.
- Activity draw: Presence of shops, cafes, cultural venues, or street life.
- Human presence: Signs of people interacting or socializing.
- Novelty: Unique or surprising elements that attract attention.

Rate the scene from 1-10 (1 = dull, 10 = highly interesting) and explain the score in 2-3 English sentences.

Respond in JSON:
{"score": <number 1-10>, "reasoning": "<English explanation>"}

dimensions.theory_base: SAGAI baseline dimension - visual aesthetics and appeal
dimensions.description: Evaluate cleanliness, greenery, architectural quality, and visual harmony.
dimensions.vlm_prompt:
Please evaluate the **Aesthetics** of this street view image.

Focus on:
- Cleanliness: Is the environment tidy and well-maintained?
- Greenery quality: Quantity and health of trees, planters, and landscaping.
- Architectural care: Building facades, materials, and upkeep.
- Harmony: How well colors, proportions, and forms work together.

Rate the scene from 1-10 (1 = unattractive, 10 = very beautiful) and explain the score in 2-3 English sentences.

Respond in JSON:
{"score": <number 1-10>, "reasoning": "<English explanation>"}

comparison_notes.vs_streetagent: StreetAgent uses sequential analysis and theory-grounded dimensions; SAGAI uses simple point aggregation
comparison_notes.vs_ewing_handy: Ewing & Handy focuses on urban design qualities; SAGAI is more general baseline
comparison_notes.vs_kaplan: Kaplan uses environmental psychology framework; SAGAI is practical assessment oriented
comparison_notes.use_case: Baseline comparison, traditional walkability metrics, large-scale screening

limitations.sequential_gaps: Cannot detect hidden barriers or sudden quality drops
limitations.transition_blind: Misses important spatial transitions and experience shifts
limitations.aggregation_bias: Mean score may hide problematic segments
limitations.no_context: Each point evaluated independently without route context

advantages.fast_deployment: Quick to deploy on new datasets
advantages.baseline: Good reference point for comparing advanced methods
